<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ignore_sigpipe:
```c
static void
ignore_sigpipe (void)
{
  struct sigaction oldsig;
  struct sigaction sig;

  sig.sa_handler = &catcher;
  sigemptyset (&sig.sa_mask);
#ifdef SA_INTERRUPT
  sig.sa_flags = SA_INTERRUPT;  /* SunOS */
#else
  sig.sa_flags = SA_RESTART;
#endif
  if (0 != sigaction (SIGPIPE, &sig, &oldsig))
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The call chain here is ignore_sigpipe -> fprintf (with strerror as an argument). Neither fprintf nor strerror calls ignore_sigpipe, so there is no direct or indirect recursive call. A concrete violation would require a cycle such as ignore_sigpipe calling fprintf which (directly or via other functions) calls ignore_sigpipe again — that does not occur in this fragment.
